/trv/ is a slow board, so don't expect immediate responses. CHECK THE CATALOG – you might find threads already discussing topics you're interested in.

Before asking for suggestions, tell /trv/ about your:

>Interests

General culture questions >>>/int/
Politics discussion >>>/pol/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So for me its:

>United Kingdom
Well, uh, known for its weather.
British rowhouses, which most of the country lives in, are quite literally shit, combining the worst aspects of having to maintain your own house and the cramped aspect of a flat.
Only London, Oxford, Cambridge and Scotland and offer something worthwhile. The average English city like Manchester, Leeds, Birmingham is grim.

>Sweden
Extremely grim weather. It has nice summers, but outside of that, it's just unsuited for human habitat imo.
Has some of the worst ghettoes I've experienced in Europe, if not THE worst. Yes, worse than France.
Cities are okay, but nothing special. Even the historical architecture in Sweden isn't all that captivating.
The whole spirit of the place seemed off and unappealing to me.

Only thing good about Sweden was that average people have a good standard of living and you could tell.

>Spain
To add a sunny country into the mix, so it doesn't seem like I'm just complaining about the weather.
Spanish cities are LITERALLY commieblock hives. I am not exaggerating. I do not believe any other first world country (other than city states like Hong Kong or Singapore) is THIS reliant on cramped high-rises to house its populace.
Quite some visually perceivable poverty.
Spanish countryside/nature SHOULD be God-tier in theory due to how many biomes it has, but just consider that most of the land is literally yellow nothingness and the provinces suffers heavily from depopulation.
Barcelona is just as bad as Paris in terms of immigrants.

I fully acknowledge all of these places are still vastly better than something like the Middle East and wide parts of Eastern Europe and I understand why people kill for a chance to live there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2376092
Disappointing:

>Switzerland
Amazing nature, but ruined by an arrogant and boring population. Far more grim, industrial and cramped-looking areas in the cities than you'd guess by the countries' wealth.
It's still a very good place to live in and worth the travel, objectively. But I didn't get the hype. It's like a wealthy German province in terms of appeal.

Positively surprising:
>Belgium
For all the negative memes it gets, I've found a country with God-tier historical architecture, a fairly wealthy population, cities almost lacking commieblocks, an interesting cuisine influenced by both Germany (meat and beer) and France (high cuisine and cheeses), lots of European history concentrated in a small strip of land.
Yeah, Brussels isn't really first-world in many parts anymore, but that just isn't all of the country.

It's way past its historical peak, economic prospects for the young are bleak and the deep South can be a ridiculous Albania-tier shithole, but it's the #1 country worldwide in terms of architecture beauty, only France can compare. Cuisine is in no need of introduction and goes way deeper than what you perceive as a tourist. Tyrol/Alpine Italy is one of the best places on Earth.

>Austria
It's an upgraded, more sovlful Germany with mountains, cuisine, amazing nature, one of the greatest cities in Europe with Vienna, little not to like. Only thing I disliked was how wages are lower than Germany, while cost of living is the same or higher.

Generally, Germany seems to be some cheater country: it's somehow CHEAPER than most of Europe, despite having better job prospects. But it's not as charming as many neighbors, I seldom was outright impressed.

>>2376095
I live in Switzerland, and think your impressions are fair. I don’t find the cities as grim as you seem to—I live on the poorer side of a city with several unattractive industrial districts, and can assert that even the crummy parts are generally relatively clean and safe compared to their counterparts nearly everywhere else. They are plagued with an overarching tendency towards bland minimalist architecture for the exteriors of recent (1960s-1990s) builds; most Swiss apartment-dwellers don’t care what the outsides of their buildings look like, so all the cozy/attractive aspects are inside and many buildings look almost like commieblocks. And rich bored teenagers like to spray paint walls. But they’re nice inside and I give my city very high marks for quality of life even though only a minority of neighborhoods are beautiful and there’s little reason for a tourist to visit. I think the ONLY RURAL SWITZERLAND IS REAL SWITZERLAND posters that sometimes stop by are both wrong and fucking nuts, but admit that for a visitor the cities shouldn’t be the major draw.

Also agree that people more often than not are unfriendly, particularly in German-speaking cantons, but some of that is due to secret but widespread shyness. I have good Swiss friends now, but it took them a couple of years to open up to me.

Also, Swiss food is inferior to that of its neighboring countries (except Germany, with which it’s probably a draw; Austria at least has schnitzel and better pastry/café options), while costing 40%-200% more.

>>2376078
I don’t like Germany much; it’s not actively offensive, but I find it dull and a lot less efficient than its reputation, and the food does nothing for me. >What's the French part like? I've been to Piemonte, close to the Swiss border a lot, sometimes I wonder what Ticino is like with them being Italian speaking.
The Romande (French Switzerland) is marginally less uptight and unfriendly than German speaking areas, but it’s still a nation of fusspots. Some better food options but nothing compared to France. Numerous excellent local wines that don’t get exported, although German-speaking Switzerland has its share of them as well.

My wife and I joke that Ticino is either the most anal part of Northern Italy or the least anal part of Switzerland. Picture a Northern Italy where everything is clean and functional, things cost at least twice as much. the architecture has a Germanic note, and strangers might scold you. Some lovely lakeside areas and some of the country’s most attractive (tiny) cities and towns. People in tourist areas are mostly close to bilingual in Italian and German, which is amusing. My kids often trip up and order stuff in German, and invariably get effective German replies.

No, it's definitely harder to leave China than to come back.
As long as you have the right visa or chinese citizenship, you can come back to China as long as you're willing to do the test and quarantine bullshit.

To give you another example, my mother who's currently there (with a foreign passport) could travel within the country, but her sister (Chinese citizenship) got blocked and couldn't board the train, when there was an inter-city travel ban for most people. Foreigners could get away with it, but Chinese people couldn't even move anywhere in their own country, so yeah, let alone GOING OUT for fun, good luck.

Again what's happening in China varies greatly not only on a daily basis but also on cities. Each city is different, more or less harsh; the harshest being in northern China, and Beijing is still a shitshow despite things becoming better in the southern part of the country since yesterday.

I am literally half-chink, I have relatives and friends there, and I haven't seen them in 3 years. China is nowhere as bad as some China-bashing people would like to paint it, but its current situation is nowhere as good as the many shills who have invaded 4chan try to depict. There's an inbetween but the very specific current corona situation is more "stupid and bad" than "nothing".

cubabro answering question from last thread......theirs still lots of drugs in the Philippines. the war on drugs was mostly a larp, they shot a bunch of squatters and tin shacks but the major chinese drug dealers still operate. Meth is still the drug of choice here as it allows people to work longer hours spend less on food. A small bag of that (punta) is like 200-500 pesos depending and it will keep you up all day so its afforable to the working man.

Weed is available, as it grows wild in the Philippines, but I would proceed with caution especially if your a fresh off the plane tourist and you don't know anybody. DO NOT trust people on the street trying to sell you shit......best case scenario, they'll sell you a half gram of dirt weed for 20-30 dollars, medium case scenario they'll run off with the money, worst case they'll try to set your ass up

Another thing to consider if you do manage to score some weed is where are you gonna smoke it? Most likely your gonna be staying in a hotel or condo, and many of those are non smoking. Forget about smoking on the street.....Filipinos are notoriously NOSEY and will inquire as to what your doing at any and all times. Even weak bud.... it stinks and .the smell wafts and lingers..... and theirs always at least 38 guards in any given hotel or condo snooping around. I really would only suggest smoking if you had a private house that your gonna be staying in for a while so you can remove the smell before you move out

Lastly , if you do ever get involved in drugs here, even if it just smoking pot for recreation NEVER EVER EVER tell anyone you use drugs. You keep that between whoever you buy it from and yourself. Never let whoever you buy from know where you are staying.....tell him you are staying in caloocan when really you stay in pasay, use an alias and/or a fake facebook account. DO NOT offer drugs to your bitches, they can and will use it against you if you have a fight....they can easily snitch and get you deported

FavelaSpic here dropping some knowledge on the Cebu provinces. People always complain that every SEA General devolves into coomer nonsense, so I'll try to appease the treekers here.....lets try be diplomatic na sirs/maams

I must tell you, if you never been to the Philippines and are planning a trip, do not make the province your first stop, ESPECIALLY if your just coming for your internet GF. You never meet a girl in the province, always in the city, and then you go to her province later if you feel comfortable with her. When I say city, I mean a city with an international airport......Manila, Cebu, or Davao......Angeles is a hooker city, if your talking to a girl from Angeles its a high chance shes a hooker whose just lied to you and told you she works at the sogo hotel as a "receptionist" but if your okay with that then carry on soldier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2368483
Talisay/Minglanilla: These are suburbs of Cebu city. You'll be able to find larger homes for rent here at reasonable rates. 30-35k (560$-700$) will get you quite a nice home. Talisay also has a nice plaza thats kino at night...they call it TPARK in the local lingo...LOTS of chickens running around.....and when I say chicken I mean horny young women between the ages of 18-22

Naga/San Fernando: I have no idea what goes on here. Its a suburb of a surburb, I never went up into every mountain parts of these neighborhoods , but its proabably just sarisari stores, vulcanizing shops, karoke machines, and crowing roosters.They also have a really big cement plant, so if your into heavy industry instead of cooming you can go look at dudes make cement. The only place I can recommend here is blueridges mountain resort. Rooms are 2k, but it has a kino view of the mountainside and a nice pool. Do bring a date and preferrebaly your own transportation though....its a trek up that mountain for sure.

CarCar: This is the end of the suburbs of suburbs, and the start of the province proper. The have a roundabout in their plaza, and you have the option of going right, or continuing straight. For the purpose of this guide we will continue straight heading south along the coastal road

Sibonga: Nothing to see here. They have a wet market if you are staying in a nearby resort and want to grill some meats.

Argao: Check out mahayahay beach if you're on a budget, the maayo hotel if your on a medium budget, or panorama de argao for a kino view of the mountains and more luxurious hotel experience

Dalaguete: They have a beach that I would classify as "MEHHH". Osmena peak is nice little mountain trek everyone knows, kino views. One of the presidents of the Philippines actually crached his plane there, so go look at some history you non-coomers.

Alcoy: Tingko beach is kino, do visit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2368484
Boljoon: Bunch of resorts along the coast. Also has a trekking trail/waterfall.....dayhag falls. If you go to the falls do ask a Kuya to guide you there as it's easy to get lost because the cell phone signal will drop that far into the interior of the island, rendering your google maps or whatever useless. The roads are shitty going up there so either be a more experienced motorcycle driver or let kuya drive and backride.

Oslob: Ahhhhh the famous Oslob. Every tourist tout will try to get you to go here. You can swim with some whale sharks for 1k pesos, locals are 500 pesos......photographs will be 500 pesos. You will see alot of boomers with their 20 year gfs here. It's the most basic bitch tourist attraction in the whole of Cebu. Tumalog falls is also nice, do visit there. IF you like spanish colonial history, you can go look at the old church complex, and if your a cubabro you can reminisce on the time that "WE WUZ KANGZ". DO check out Sumilon island as well, just off the coast of oslob.

Santander: Most southern part of Cebu island. Nothing really of note here except a boat that can transport you to Siquijor......you might be able to get a boat to Dumaguete here as well. Here we will loop around the start heading north along the western coast of Cebu.

Samboan: They have about 4 different treks/waterfall here. Agunid, Binalayan, balay sawa, and Dao. All of them are easy treks, except for Dao. I wouldn't recommend Dao if your a fatfuck, or if you're with older people, its a true jungle trek but the falls are kino.

Ginatilan: Inambakan is one of my favorite falls in Cebu, truly beautiful. Kabutongan falls is also in this town, but I would classify it as "MEHH"

Malabuyoc: Nothing really of note here. Handigan falls is a trekking area, you can have a jungle picnic with your flip waifu here.

Alegria: 3 waterfalls here. Cambais, Cangkalanog, Montpieller. Again, you better be a good navigator, motorcycle driver, and be able to talk bisaya if you want to get to these. I would recommend getting a kuya at the plaza to guide you, the roads can be treacherous and unmarked on google maps.

Badian: This is home to the famous Kawasan falls, the runner up for most basic bitch tourist attraction in Cebu. Every tout will recommend you this. You will see groups of Asian tourists walking around with life vests and helmets, touts will harasss you almost non stop, and you'll hardly be able to walk or enjoy the view because of the crowds. It's the only place I've ever seen a fucking traffic jam at a waterfall I'm being dead ass serious. Lambug beach is also located here, and is probably one of the best public beaches in Cebu.....white sand, blue water, not rocky, accommodation on the beach etc. Kansanto springs is a more local spot where you can have a picnic and a cold swim.

Moalboal: This is a nice beach town. Lots of foreigners here. Split between 2 beaches....White Beach and Panagsama. White beach is more suitable to swimming as its less rocky, but you'll have less choice of accomidation and they will be of lower quality. Panagsama beach is a bit more rocky, but they have better accommodation/food choices there. It's one of the few places in the province that has some semblance of a nightlife. Chili bar is nice during sunset, and they used to have a disco that had lots of beautiful women in there, both pinay and foreign, but I'm not sure if it survived the pandemic. I went there recently but it was during a weekday and it was closed, but they might open the disco on weekends

Cubabro here sharing some more knowledge. Today's topic is MALLS. I know I know.....many of you despise malls because you're coming from America/Europe/Australia and the malls there are dead at best, and souless centers of consumerism at worst...but hear me out. Malls in the Philippines serve many functions. MOST (not all.....all you conyo Filipinos shut the fuck up, sit down and listen) Filipinos can't actually afford anything in the larger malls. They go there because it's one of the few places they can get free aircon/wifi, people watch, window shop, variety of foods etc. They are some of the cleanest and best maintained places in the Philippines. This being said, these are some of the most densely populated places, and if your mission is hunting for a girl/boy/ladyboy WHATEVER, these are great places and must not be overlooked. Not only do malls provide traditional shopping, but they provide fianancial services (money transfers.....western union, money gram etc), and package delivery (DHL, UPS etc), along with being transportaion hubs for public utility vehichles (PUVS). This combination insures these places are always filled with people from opening to close.

I will share every mall in Cebu city proper with a brief description. Firstly, their are tiers of malls, and you will find a different type of person depending on the tier.
1. Ayala malls
2. Sm malls
3.Robinsons
4. Gaisano
5. Random shit. Puregold/fishermall/starmall/ ETC

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cebu city mall list:

1. Ayala Center: This is the best mall in cebu city. Centrally located in the buisness district and equipped with a beautiful courtyard. Their are many nice hotels situated within walking distance to this malls. Freelance hookers can be found prowling, especially around bo's coffee, tgiFridays, and the Social (bar/lounge located on the top level.....infamous for foreigner hunters). Many food options here ranging from classic Filipino, to Greek. They have a cinema if going to the movies is your thing. Must visit if in Cebu city.

2. SM CITY: Oldest major mall (I think) in Cebu. Located on Ouano avenue (a main artery of Cebu). Every person will know how to get here by instinct, I would consider this as the proverbial heart of Cebu. The Radisson blu is connected to the mall (nicer hotel with great lobby), and the bayfront hotel is across the street (midrange hotel). The mall itself is showing it's age. They have a bowling alley and cinema for entertaining your family.

3. SM Seaside: Newest major mall situated on the main road leading out of Cebu City. It's also connected to the newly constructed bridge (CCLEX), so it's the closet major mall to those living/staying in LapuLapu city/Cordova. Nice complex with a kino roof area/lounge. Seaside has a cinema and a ice skating rink. The cebu ocean park is also connected to the mall......an okay aquarium by international standards, but with a nice restaurant attached.....kino views and very instagramable for your girlfriend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2368769
4. Robinsons Galleria: Located just up the road from SM City. Has a decent hotel attached to the complex (summit galleria) . Has a tgifridays AND denny's (many memories of drunken fights at 3am in my local dennys in Miami.....here in the Philippines its a "classy" resturant LOOOL).

5. Robinsons Fuente: Located in Osmena circle, right up the street from the infamous mango square. On the first floor, theirs a vendor who sells "TOBACCO" pipes and rolling papers.....other than that it's not much in there except your standard fastfood and grocery store.

6. Parkmall: Located in Mandaue adjacent to BAI hotel. Mixed indoor/outdoor mall with a grocery store and lots of food options. Major transportation hub for PUV's. Good people watching in the afternoon for a more local flavor

7. City Times square: This can be considered part of parkmall as it right across the street. Outdoor stripmall type......has a few good bars and restaurants attached. Queensland hotel is here as well, for all your short time boomboom needs.

8. Pacific mall MANDAUE: Located just off the bridge coming from lapulapu city. Medium sized mall with your standard Jolibee/chowking offerings. Transportation hub for those headed into the northern suburbs of cebu

9. J Centre Mall (Jmall): Medium sized mall located in Mandaue. Most notable feature is their Bureau of Immigration office. If you live here as a foreigner for a while you will need to come here eventually. Decent hotel attached, and a nice bar (SENTRAL) located 1 minute walk away.

10. Elizabeth mall (Emall): Located adjacent to the south bus terminal. Smaller mall. Has a ghetto public school (ACT) attached, good place to people watch. For some reason I see ALOT of Africans in this mall, I can't fucking explain it, but I'm working on figuring it out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2368785
11. Ayala Central Block: Newer mall situated in IT park across the street from the park social and sugbu mercado. Lots of call center people open to foreigners around this area. Make sure to tell your driver AYALA in IT PARK, because if you just say "Ayala" they will take you to the Ayala center for sure.
12. JY Centre: Smaller mall in the Lahug neighborhood with a few food options, and a Mcdonalds for the Amerimutts. This is mainly used a jump off point for those going up into the mountains to see the TOPS viewpoint. Lots of motortaxi drivers will hang out here and try to take you up the mountain on a tour

13. Gaisano country mall: Outdoor Shopping area located in Mandaue. I've driven by this many times but never went in, so I can't really report as to what's there, but it IS THERE.

14. Gaisano Main/138 mall/Colonade: I've included these all together as they are in the same general vicinity (walking distance). All three of these are on, or very near to Colon street. Most Gaisano "malls" are not really malls so to speak, but more like big department stores. 138 and colonade sell a bunch of cheap knockoff shit from China, but theirs some good looking girls in there I'LL TELL YOU WHATTTTT

15.Gaisano Tisa/Gaisano jai alai/Gaisano mandaue central/Gaisano mandaue north: YEA theirs like 10 of these things in the greater Cebu area, I'm sure I'm missing some, so cebuBros correct me if I'm missing anything. These are more ghetto malls, your gonna see lots of flip flops, basketball shorts, knockoff basketball jerseys, and ankle bracelets. No frills here, this is a mall for locals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369016
16. SM Consalacion: Smaller Sm mall located on the northern outskirts of Cebu. Kind of out the way if your staying in the city center, but it's the last stop before you start heading into the northern provinces.

17. Marina Mall: Located in LapuLapu city. This is mall in closet proximity to the airport. Standard jolibee/ chowking affair, nothing special. Their is another mall across the street (it's a gaisano mall), but as their is ANOTHER gaisano mall located a few meters down the road, I refer to both as Marina mall. The drivers have lived in the neighbnorhood their whole life and they still get the 2 malls mixed up, so just say Marina mall.

18. Gaisano Island mall: Located on lapu lapu a few meters from marina mall.....Known locally as Island mall. Theirs a beauru of immigration office inside, so if you live in lapulapu, its much more convient than going all the way into the city for your visa extensions.

19. Tamiya: This is an outdoor outlet style mall. On google maps, this is marked as "THE SHOPS AT PUEBLO VERDE", or "PUEBLO VERDE". If you tell a driver to take you to Pueblo verde, he will look at you like your stupid. For some reason everyone calls this area tamiya, you have to say tamiya or they won't know where the fuck you're talking about. I have many fond memories in Tamiya. Pre-pandemic they used to have a disco and a restobar in here, and I picked up quite a few girls just drinking in front of the 7/11 there (not hookers just horny young women). It's a bit more subdued now, but it's still a major transportation hub for LapuLapu city and they have several large factories nearby, so this place gets packed with people in the late afternoon. LOTS OF BEAUTIFUL GIRLS who work in factories making 200 dollars a month praying and hoping you'll save them can be found in this area. Try to brighten up their life, but don't take advantage please.

>Why Taiwan ?
why not ? it's Asia on easy level, tons of friendly people, nicest expat community that isn't weeb or druggies or coomers

>No, seriously, why ?
Great emphasis on industry so all engineers are welcome
They recruit a lot of TEFL and it's relatively well paid compared to the average salary on the island, great if you don't have any student debt to deal with
Taipei is absolutely gorgeous, the skyline may not be up to standards compared to the megacities of Asia but it's a nice place with all the amenities of a world-class city
Rent is relatively cheap compared to the other big places in Asia, easily comparable to Thailand (albeit with a roughly 20% markup)
Street food is cheap and delicious
Taiwan has a rich and multicultural history that allows them to be ok with the concept of being a foreigner

>Is Taiwan the real China ?
No, ROC isn't the real china, it's an offshoot as much as the PRC is. Taiwan has been impacted by japanese culture a lot whereas the PRC modified radically china's culture through the cultural revolution. Both represent significant aspects of the Chinese civilization and you should go to both if you're truly interested.

>How can I immigrate/expatriate/live in Taiwan ?
Work Visa, Working Holiday Visas, Gold Card Visa, Student visa, and Chinese Student visa. and whatever investor scheme i can't be arsed to look up. Always make sure you consult your local Taiwanese embassy (likely referred as a taipei representative office in your country). Keep in mind the latter two make you eligible for a couple of grants and allow you to work (you need a work permit but it's easy to get).

>cooming in taiwan ?

>Where can I stay and have a nice time

A guy made a cool map on another thread.

>the problem with the taiwanese downtown is that it spans half the fucking city with many nevralgic centers (Dongmen, Ximen, 101, Technology Building, Main Station, Digital Plaza around Songjiang Nanjing etc.). So as long as you're within the city limits (even if you're not, you're never THAT far), It'll take you as much time to walk to the station than to get to your station of choice. I highly suggest living near the green line (so, the green zone) because that practically gets you anywhere and is well connected to the red Line (which basically covers the more expensive Da'an area). You could also consider living up north where the black area is. This is where a lot of older expats live, but i don't know much about it besides Yuanshan with its Maji Square (and its Triangle)

You want cheap but nice addresses, look around Wanshan and Zhongzheng District. If that's too much, you can still settle for something around Xindian without missing out on the rest of Taipei since it's not that far. Also, the 648 bus basically goes from the deeper end of xindian all the way to City Hall, so even if you're a cheap hack you can make do with that. Because yes, knowing how the buses work in Taipei will save you a *lot* of money.

posts.com: Me and family will be in Taipei soon for a trip. Any cool shit that isn't the usual tourist spot like Taipei 101?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2371940
A complicated question that highly depends on the skills you have, your ability to socialize and network with locals and your luck. For such questions i usually suggest you go there and find out provided you have some minimal amount of things you can bring to the table (such as some kind of professional experience in a field).

>>2374819
He's right you know. Countries, especially Asia, put a high emphasis on degrees when it comes to work visas. Sometimes having a degree is mandatory, and also having some work experience too. Also, maybe they don't even hire in your field, or you would need to speak mandarin to somehow level the field.

>>2375127
Taipei 101 is definitely worth visiting. There's also the linjiang night market nearby too. Also, elephant mountain is a bit of a climb but the view is worth it.

Also, Taipei main station has some very cool underground malls, more precisely Beimen Station. You can find lots of weeb stuff there as well as some nice goodies and souvenirs you can bring with you. In general, if you're not planning to go to Japan any time soon, Taiwan in general is a great source of weeb shit you can gift or keep for yourself.

All the night markets to visit are omnipresent on the internet so i won't bother you with them.

Definitely go to Ximending, it's a nice bustling neighborhood. There's also the Guanghua digital plaza if you're looking for electronics. Definitely haggle if you're there. They've got great deals.

The Gongguan river park is really nice this time of year, definitely rent some bikes and go there, it's really nice. The Gongguan area in general is my favorite, they've got the best all you can eat hotpots too and there's NTU too. Also, the neighborhood around Technology building (north of NTU and gongguan) is good looking with lots of cool restaurants.

I highly recommend the museums too. CKS memorial, palace museum, etc.

Oh and definitely try to escape taipei for an evening and plan a trip to Keelung.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you wanna visit a comfy town, you can take the ferry from Batangas to Romblon. The town is fairly small, yet charming. Just a short motorcycle-ride away, you got Bonbon beach which is usually quite pristine, and you also have Logbon island just a short boat-ride away.

Besides, this is the marble capital of the country, so you can buy nice marble figures and misc. for quite cheap. There's also an Italian restaurant there ran by an actual Italian with pizza that tastes quite good considering the logistical implications of running it there.
Although the island is quite small, you can take a small ferry to Tablas which has lot's of nice beaches around and some outdoor activites, or to Sibuyan which is less developed but has a 2,000m mountain that is quite challenging to hike(takes 2 days), so if hiking is your thing, check that one out. Also Cresta de Gallo is one of my favourite islands.

>>2372901
That's Inambakan in Southern Cebu. Very nice falls consiting of 3 levels. However, not too far away is also Dao Falls(pic related) which is much more majestic, and requires a 30min trek along the stunning river that leads up to it. Almost straight out of a fairytale.
To get to either of these, you can avail of either a tour agency in Moalboal, or if you are not a complete retard on a scooter, you can rent one and go by yourself.

>Would like to a do a few things off the beaten path if possible, any recommendations?
In Bohol, go to Dimiao. There are 4 popular waterfalls there, and it's quite far so barely any tourists there either. You may come accross Kuya RJay, the tour guide there. He's pretty cool and fun. Tell him you hate Russians and he will love you.
If you have time, check out Anda Beach, pretty nice. Also it's close to Cam-Umantad falls and some kino rice terraces.
DON'T RIDE IN THE DARK YOU ARE PLAYING WITH THE DEVIL IF SO. And I'm not talking about getting robbed, I am talking about the traffic hazards, like poorly lit roads that could have obstacles in them that you can't see, borderline psychopathic bus and van-drivers, dogs suddenly running accross the road infront of you.

cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2372901
>>2373189

>Loboc river seems interesting but I've heard mixed reviews about river cruise
It's cool to do once, but that's about it. There are some paved roads that go along the river or close to it so you can check out through that.

>Also chocolate hills and tarsiers... is it crowded and touristy?
Barely any tourists in the Tarsier Sanctuary last time I was there. Be sure to go early.
Chocolate Hills can get quite crowded. However, there's a "secret" area though that you can go to. You can climb ontop of one of the hills there right by the road and have a great view. Pic related
Not too far from the Chocolate Hills there's something called Pangas Falls.

>Also places for food/entertainment, I will try anything.
In Cebu City, check out 8flix & Chill. There they serve Tuslob Buwa. To spoil it for you, it's basically pork brain mixed with chili, onion and onions sauce. It turns into a gravy which you dip "puso", or rice balls in. As disgusting as it might sound to most, it's actually really good. Imagine dipping bread in a buttery gravy full of umami. That's pretty much what it is. It's dirt cheap too, $4 for 10 piece of rice balls and unlimited gravy.
Top of Cebu is another nice restaurant to check out.

In Bohol, Mist is a cool interesting restaurant made in the vernacular style. Molly Bistro is similar, though they primarily serve a Filipino/Viet BBQ fusion.
Bamboo place is usually where the nightlife is in Alona/Tawala.
Be on the lookout for Beefarm Ice cream along Alona Beach. Really delicious. And on that topic, The Buzzz Cafe is pretty nice. Check out Halang Halang, a Bisaya soup similar to Tom Kha Gai.

If you go to Balicasag, don't fucking eat anything there. I am an advocate for promoting Filipino food and even I found the food there very mediocre. Also it's a ripoff, $10 for a single plate of an awful meal. If they still sell barbecue in Virgin Island, I suggest you to avoid the touts. It's good but extremely overpriced.

Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2372901
>>2373189
>>2373197

>Worth it to rent motorbikes everywhere or is it dangerous?
If you have common sense, you'll be fine most likely. Don't drive like a maniac, get used to the bike first. Don't do steep turns(if you know how to truly countersteer) if there is dust or dirt on the road. Keep an eye on the rear mirrors. If you see a van, bus or any big car approaching you fast, steer to the right shoulder to let them pass. These drivers have no brains, but you don't want them to harm you either.
Before you rent a bike, check that both the front and rear brakes are good, that means you shouldn't have to squeeze/press them too hard to actually stop. Check for air in the tyres, they should be rock hard.
Ask the renters to check oil.
Honk whenever you are passing someone, or think someone who is at perpendicular interchange haven't seen. Use the horn alot to let people know you are there.
Bohol and Siquijor are great places to rent. Coron you won't really need.

>Any way to avoid food poisoning or should I just bring Cipro and pray?
I honestly think it all depends on your gut most of the time. I've been food poisoned here a few times but that was after staying here for many months. Meanwhile, my friend and his gf was here for only 4 days and they both got food poisoned, but not me. But yeah, you are likely to experience some kind of diarrhea sooner or later

cont.

>>2372901

>>2373200
>Any other tips/advice for Philippines I'd appreciate.
Use Grab when going around in the cities. Taxi drivers in this region is notorious for ripping people off, although I ironically had no problem using Taxis in Cebu City, the 3 drivers were honest and used a non-rigged meter.
A 10min ride with tricycle should not cost more than P150-200. If they say anything above, haggle or just go for another driver.
Don't be swayed by touts, be on the look for the best deal. If you can't find, give in to them and hear what they offer.
Ignore hawkers unless they have something you really need and can't acquire easily in that moment, eg. drybag.
I suggest you learn how to use the "tabo" when taking a shit. It will save you space not having to bring rolls everywhere.
Don't be afraid to ask locals for directions.
There are probably more stuff but I can't recall much right now.

>Would like to a do a few things off the beaten path if possible, any recommendations?
About Coron, if you have time and money, do a Dugon tour. It's one of my favourite activites I've ever done. Contact this guy for more info:
https://www.instagram.com/freedivewithlouie/

There are also alot of Japanese shipwrecks there from WWII that are worth to check out if you have your scuba cert in place. I think they will only let you dive in the cargo ship as it's very easy to traverse.

It’s more of an /out/ country in my opinion. Lot’s of neat outdoor activities you can do such as hiking, canyoning, scuba diving(BIG emphasis on this one), free diving, surfing, expedition tours, island hopping. Night life can be fun here aswell.
Culture-wise, many will tell you they are Mexicans of Asia, but I rather think they have a maritime Asian culture. Lot’s of emphasis on sea-faring in a tropical climate, with a few Asian elements here and there, and also a few Spanish elements.
In my opinion, the most glaring American influence is in the language, brutalist architecture, basketball, (barely functional) political structure, urban planning and some food items the mutts unfortunately introduced. Reggae is also quite popular in the sea-side communities due to this.
If you’re American(Fil-Ams are notoriously bad at cooking) give the country’s cuisine atleast one more chance by dining in well-regarded establishments such as Manam and Gerry’s Grill. It has potential unironically, but the average flip puts no soul into it.

This country is amazing for fishing, and has plenty of kino landscapes.

And lastly, the country has some of the finest beaches in the world in my opinion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you’re living out there you have to haul yourself to work in snowy windy darkness for several months straight. It’s very tough mentally. Icelanders also have the customary Nordic aloofness with foreigners which is very hard to penetrate (they’re great once you’re through that barrier). Also shit costs a fucking tonne even on Icelandic telephone number money.

But you do get to really explore the country - and also if you want to visit really remote places like Greenland and Faroes you can do it easily if expensively from Reykjavík.

One thing is ISK. Will you be managing a tight budget all the time? Or are they paying you a fortune to babysit some government agency’s computers? I wouldn’t have enjoyed it nearly as much if I had to be parsimonious constantly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2360364
I know Madrid has been mentioned already, but Barcelona is by FAR my favourite city in the world to stay in, especially long term. I'm eventually planning on moving there.

For me, Barcelona is the perfect mix of a big, industrial modern cosmopolitan city, with beautiful historic architecture and a refreshing combination of both chilled out beach/party/tourist elements and normal every-day working life.

Madrid is very similar, except a more conservative, more administrative city with far less touristic/party elements. For me, I could explore Barcelona for several weeks, seeing new parts of the city, meeting people from all over the world, visiting interesting museums, relaxing at different beaches and eating at different types of restaurants and not get bored. I could probably only do the same in Madrid for several days.

Honestly, I don't have a single negative thing to say about Barcelona.

Bruv, as a fellow Brazilian that has been living in Ireland for the past 6 years, and having travelled to over 56 countries I can easily answer that.

First of all: money. Third World is cheap and I really mean CHEAP. Fancy restaurants and hotels that are too expensive for locals, are actually cheaper than shitty places in Europe, for instance.

My rent in Ireland is 2000 euros per month. With that amount alone, I could live in a 5 stars hotel for almost half a month. A SHITTY bland food in a restaurant in Ireland will cost me around 90 euros, for two people, while in Brazil it costs like 40 euros to eat in a really good restaurant with tasty food.

Then you have culture itself. Brazilians are FUN people, period. Try mingling with Norwegians or germans. They are ALL socially awkward, unless dead drunk. Brazilian women are also 100x hotter than Americans/Europeans.

There's also the weather. Irish/UK weather is terrible. It's cold, damp and dark 360 days a year, while you can go to the beach all year long in Brazil.

Also, beaches in Brazil are great compared to beautiful but sad beaches in the Mediterranean. Most beaches in Greece are not sandy but made of hard pebbles that hurt as hell to walk on.

Everything I said about Brazil also applies to other third-world countries such as Thailand, the Philippines, Mexico, the Caribbean... Going there as a dweller of a first-world country just instantly give you more leverage and higher purchase power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The prices vary a lot. You can do it in Chiang Mai for 4000 baht a month. This is training up to twice a day, 6 days a week (2 hour sessions).

Suggest getting your own wraps and gloves. They're the only up front costs.

You can get an education visa for muay thai, but if you have a strong passport you can easily get 60 days (pre-apply for tourist visa) then extend for another 30 days. Try it for a few months first, then if you really love it, go for a long term visa.

It's hard. I went twice a day for the first week and burned out. Ended up trying to go as much as I could, but probably averaged out to around 5 times a week. It's awesome though.

>>2369998
It's partially true.
But also you need a reality check. It's high temperature, high humidity, and your body will get hammered just trying to train in that. Assume 3 sessions a week while your body adjusts.

So even if it was a top tier gym, for the average joe, you wouldn't be able for it unless you have a few years of muay thai practice behind you,

Also as a warm up, every morning they run 5k (while it's still relatively cool). If you can't do the warm up, you'll take a few extra months to get your body in order

TLDR; this is not a 40 hour a week intense training, if you're a newbie.

So a 2nd tier gym is perfectly fine for a year, you'll be far far better than you are today after a year

Go ahead and try it. If you're on your smartphone and you see the hotel on Google Maps, it shows a low Agoda/Booking price, and you click on that link to get that price, it will forcibly open the app if you have it installed and you won't get the ultra-cheap price that they dangle on Google Maps.
If you book over your computer in a web browser, you will get the discount even if you log in with your Booking/Agoda account. That way you can still use the app for ease of references and communication.
I often book last minute on my phone, looking for the cheapest deals in my vicinity. Sometimes I'm even in the hotel and I'll ask them if they will match the booking site's rates if I pay in cash (the smaller places sometimes do), but if not I'll book on my phone, and often the cheapest prices are Agoda/Booking. That's the main reason I never install their apps. (Another good reason is all these apps are tracking you and selling your info to make money, so minimize which ones you use.)

Or to put it more clearly, if you're depressed it won't make a different to you wandering your depressed body somewhere else. The problem is within.

And fundamentally the world or rather being alive, being a human body is much of the sameness. You exist as your body and it doesn't matter where in the world you are, much if the day is spent dealing with its needs - finding shelter, cleaning, cooking, buying food, eating, finding comfort, clothes, sex, water, walking to places, etc, etc. Our lives really are just dealing with the burdens of our bodies. Just even more fundamentally every moment I'm not in deep sleep I'm adjusting my position, shifting from 1 foot to the other, relieving pressure somewhere. I'm on a bus at the moment and sitting isn't just this passive comfortability - it's an active constant shift of weight and pressure. It hurts to sit for long periods of time. This is just an illustration of how burdensome our bodies are.

And really, how different are other places anyway? It's just the content of what your sense changes, rather than the structure. There's still your body, your visual field, the sounds you hear. What's really changing? The trees might look a little different, the foods might taste a little different. Nothing fundamentally has changed. You're still a body of burdens in an external world that is cold and indifferent to your needs.

Just keep in mind that "tourism", "travelling" is an industry. It's a way for people to make a living by selling ideas and experiences to rich foreigners. Going to another place is like consuming a product. Oh you've "done" Italy?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2374739
The material is changing. And if the material changes, there is a huge probability that you will change as you are a product of your environment to which your thoughts reflect upon and your acts interact with. Simply put, by changing your environment, you can change yourself.
But it has to be a meaningful experience. If all you do is go to a hotel, do some sightseeing for a couple of days and then come back, then yes, you're not doing shit. But if you do it in a certain way, travel can be great shock therapy by putting you in a completely novel environment and make you become someone you couldn't have been by staying put. We are not beings of pure willpower capable of changing in a vacuum. And moving to a very different physical and cultural location can be a good catalyst for change.
Of course, if it is a short term experience where you shelter yourself and keep yourself in your comfort zone (i.e doing nothing really novel) by really just doing what you could do back home, you're not doing shit. It's like going to the beach. You've definitely made the effort to move from your home which is dry to an area where you can get wet, but if you didn't go ahead and made an effort to swim, you're still dry, so you haven't really achieved anything.

Doesn't mean you can't enjoy yourself, though. But if you want to do something meaningful, there is an extra effort you must bring forth.


However Emerson does have a few quotes about travelling that hilariously fit /trv/ :

>I am not much an advocate for traveling, and I observe that men run away to other countries because they are not good in their own, and run back to their own because they pass for nothing in the new places. Las Vegas has some of the best entertainment and dining in the world, and you never have to set foot in a casino (although I would just to see the freaks that haunt the floor, it’s great people-watching).

Asking “any good food” is impossibly broad, it depends on what you’re looking for and what your budget is. I like Craftsteak at the MGM, Julian Serrano at the Aria, and (of course) you should do at least one buffet, Caesar’s is famous for a reason.

Zak Bagan’s Haunted Museum looks interesting, lots of spoopy artifacts. I haven’t gone but it’s on my list.

And then of course you can catch a show. I’m a Beatles fan so I’ve seen Love at the Mirage a few times — but there are literally hundreds to choose from. Sometimes it’s fun to catch a random comic who you would never seek out… like Carrot Top does a fucking hilarious show, actually.

Lastly, those gun ranges where you go and pay $200 to pop a glock 10 times… incredibly overrated and overpriced BUT if you’ve got a younger kid around, it will be the highlight of the trip for him. I actually really enjoyed taking a young cousin to Battlefield and letting him rail on the full auto BAR.

Not OP but came back from Vegas a couple of days ago. Despite all the negativity I'm about to post, I enjoyed myself a lot. Random thoughts:

Holy fuck everything is expensive, even as someone who goes to London a lot it's eye watering. Fuck those scam convenience stores in hotels where nothing is priced. Knew I was going to get ripped off so I tried experimenting just buying a can of Monster. 8 fucking dollars. That aside, almost off the buffets now are comically expensive, $75 for a dinner? May as well go to a nice restaurant and have a 3 course meal with some sides, it'll be cheaper, nicer and fill you up just as much. Also much fewer to choose from

Stayed at The Flamingo which was cheap and had a god tier location but was a bit run down, insanely smokey and I'm guessing was a magnet for the worst visitors (holy fuck stop slamming your doors so hard at 3am that my bed shakes). Room was nice and clean though.

Was disappointed by the lack of effort put into xmas decorations other than at The Bellagio which literally had the most impressive xmas display I've ever seen. Big slots person so I blew loads of money at the various casinos. Slots were disappointingly homogenised, 95% of the slots were the same at every casino, no huge giant $100,000,000 megabucks displays any more (there are some large jackpot machines but they're non-descript). They're incredibly low volatility compared to UK slots, no chance of a big win, they just slowly eat your money

The shops are also really shitty now. Almost entirely high end shops. Weird going through Caesars, Aria and the Bellagio and same ultra expensive shops that are completely empty whilst the walkways outside them are packed. I know these shops don't need to make that many sales a day to make money but passing 3-4 empty Louis Vuitton shops at different casinos in a day makes suspect that they don't make any money and they're just subsidised by the casinos so they can say they have high end shopping in there.

I went in April for the Expo after planning it for two years, I had a great time. The Burj Khalifa and the Mall is obviously the first thing to do and it was amazing, probably the coolest thing I have ever seen was being up there and looking down. Get at least the VIP pass, so you can go six floors higher and skip the line, its worth it.

The expo was also great unfortunately its over, but the train goes all the way to the campus so you might still be able to check it out even though it's over.

If I were there for longer I would have went to legoland or ferarri world in abu dhabi. The old town "bur dubai" was really lively at night if you just want to cruise around late night and look for cheap food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

posts.com: Lincoln national forest was one of my favorite days during my FL to CA bike trip. Town at the top has a really good bbq place, very friendly and tasty. Alamagordo and carlsbad are the two closest cities to there and neither of them are very special but west of alamagordo is the white sands national park and a military high frequency laser testing facility then ur in las Cruces. The gila national forest is something i regret having missed out on, hot springs and an ancient native cliff dwelling. Instead of that i went south to el paso and west from there next to the border, less hills. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Born and raised in Albuquerque (Have also traveled a lot)
It’s very beautiful, also the 5th largest state so don’t expect to see everything in one trip. Coming from Colorado I recommend you start in Taos, kinda hippy dippy place but the natural setting is staggeringly beautiful. Try to see the Taos pueblo although it’s been closed a lot lately so check ahead. You could do santa fe but that place bugs the shit out of me, very expensive and filled (i mean filled) with white texas/california tourists. If you do go there I recommend the Rail yard and upper canyon road. If you’re into history La Cienaguilla petroglyphs are cool and like 15 minutes from the plaza. I highly highly recommend the Valles Caldera, you can drive in from Los Alamos and soak it in. Stop in Jemez Springs on your way down, you can check out the historic sight or just hangout at the biker bar. From their you can either go to Albuquerque or up 550 towards Farmington. If you’re headed that way go to chaco canyon. It’s a heavy place but one of the most interesting sights in all of north america. Assuming you’re gonna pass through albuquerque I recommend stopping at the frontier and getting green chili stew or enchiladas. it’s cheap it’s fast and the vibes inside are all the best of albuquerque. You’ll like it, it’s not as shit as everyone says but be aware of burglary, they won’t rob you directly but they’ll smash your window as soon as you turn around. Park near other cars and in the light you’ll be fine it’s never happened to me in over 20 years of living in ABQ.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
nature fag here, been to NM a few times, underrated place. Carlsbad Caverns is great, one of my favorite national parks. Easily my favorite cave I've been in, only good cave I've been to that you don't need to be on a guided tour also which is nice, though there are guided tours to other parts of the cave also. Haven't even seen the bat flight at Carlsbad since I always go to NM in winter when I'm snowed out from places further North, heard it's great though, must be if it's anything like the bird flights you can see at Bosque del Apache. Definitely recommend Bosque del Apache in winter, even if you're not really into birds or nature, seeing thousands or tens of thousands of large birds take flight is a special experience.
White Sands is neat enough, worth a stop.
The Sangre de Cristos around Taos are nice, nothing specatcular though, I find Valles Calderas more interesting.
The Gila Canyon area is beautiful, Jordan hot springs is an excellent backcountry hot springs, it's an adventure to get there though, if you're into backpacking at all it's a great area.
Northwest New Mexico has a lot of Badlands with crazy formations, pretty cool. Chaco Canyon is nice too, largest pueblo ruins I think, Not as scenic as Mesa Verde in Colorado but you can walk through them on your own which is nice. Lots of other Native American ruins around New Mexico also.
I've somehow neer even driven through Albuquerque or Santa Fe, I'd like to see the balloon festival sometime.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been travelling australia for 2 months by myself. I landed in melblurne went up to cairns and now I'm in darwin and I'm heading down to adelaide by New years. Here's my opinions:

>melbourne: nice, good fruit market, busy, things going on, st kinda beach part was nice. Take the boat to geelong just for the views
>canberra: fake Sims town, really just awful. No culture no vibrancy just a big strip mall really and the most deranged war museum I've ever been to
>sydney: good city, kinda grimey, but things to do, see, go on ferry to manly, take the train to katoomba and go hiking
>newcastle:nice beach and spit kinda a grimey but surfing town
>port macquarie: tonnes of bats and lizards and animals here, quite a nice place, nice beach walks
>brisbane: kinda shit. There's a free ferry that goes down the river. Mostly just a big shopping mall.
>agnes water: nice beach but tiny and fake town for tourists
>airlie beach: a fucking hellhole of drunken hald naked British tourists "doing" the whitsundays
>townsville: drunken Bogans and abos. Take the ferry to magnetic island it's nice
>cairns: hot, humid, tourist town. Good fruit market but again just too many drunken fuckkng British people
>mt isa: hell
>tenant creek: was only here a few hours, just an abo ridden shithole
>katherine: see above
>darwin: see above

Basically anything above like halfway up the east coast you don't need to even go to

Also the interior is basically just a flat scrubland with nothing to see. And the animals are meh. It's really not worth driving long dostances to see some emus and a cassowary etc. Yoy look for like 10 seconds and are like okay now what?

Melbourne and Sydney have the been the best so far. And the abos there are actual normal human beings. They are buck fucking wild in the NT.

There was the time some middle school kids made fun of me for playing weeb games at the arcade in japanese (I understood them unfortunately). There was the time some cool japanese guys invited me and my buddy to their karaoke room and I asked them about "nanpa" (picking up girls) in my shitty japanese and scared them away. Maybe none of these on their own sound that bad but they add up. I dressed like a retard, acted like an autist, and I did like anime (although I never spoke about it), and my anime-esque japanese was likely quite apparent to natives even if I didn't notice. Some coworkers told me a few years later that a work I was using was something they only heard in anime.

Honestly I don't know how I even live with myself. Thanks for reminding me I need to finish this beer and pour me some liquor. posts.com:
Real Traveller's map™ thread.

Color your home country in red, and the subdivisions you've visited in your home country in dark red. Color the countries you've visited in light green, and the subdivisions you've visited in dark green. Or just use the map however you like.

This is an updated version of the map, version 4.0.3. I'll post the simplified update in the next post.

Changelog (1/2)

Major changes
>Added three new provinces of Kazakhstan
>Azerbaijan has reorganized their economic regions from 10 to 14
>Indonesia has split their old Papua province into four new ones
>Timor-Leste has split Atauro Island from Dili Municipality
>South Ossetia's capital, Tskhinvali, has been added as a separate district
>The Israeli-administered Golan Heights has been merged to their Northern District, while also adding the eastern part of Quneitra Province to Syria. This corrects an error from previous maps where the entire Golan Heights was shown as being a separate Israeli district.
I also removed Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republics that were added in the previous update, because with everything going on, they can hardly claim to be unrecognized countries anymore. I won't change Ukraine's borders anymore until that war is over.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This is the simplified update which can be copied and pasted onto your current map for your convenience. Open MS Paint, make sure "transparent selection" is ticked, zoom into the upper left corner, and copy-paste this image onto your old map. THIS WILL ONLY WORK IF YOU HAVE MAP VERSION 4.0.2! If you have an earlier version (4.0.1 or no version number in the upper left corner), your map won't be updated properly, you have to fill out the new map.

Changelog (2/2)

Minor changes
>Adjusted some of the Cambodian and Icelandic administrative borders
>Made Dushanbe slightly bigger

Cosmetic changes
>Removed some black pixels around Sri Lanka and Crimea

In other news
>Burundi and Bangladesh
I found out that both Burundi and Bangladesh have upcoming subdivision changes, Bangladesh will add two more divisions, while Burundi will merge their 18 provinces down to 5. These changes aren't official yet, and knowing how long these things might take in that part of the world (still waiting for those Iraqi governorates announced in 2014), I didn't include them in the update.
>New Caledonia
It went completely under my radar, but New Caledonia hosted their third and final independence referendum in December 2021. It was boycotted by the pro-independence camp, who wanted to postpone it because of Covid, so the vote was overwhelmingly (96,5%) in favor of continued French rule.
>Chuuk
Another independence referendum scheduled for 2022 was that of Chuuk State in Micronesia. The referendum has been delayed many times, and appears to have been completely abandoned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2337408
Yes. Flew to Almaty, then Bishkek, then Tashkent. Trains to Kokand/Fergana & Samarkand/Bukhara. I got a double-entry visa for Uzbekistan because I considered going to Khujand, but didn't. I also didn't see Khiva. Trip was 2-3 months.

Almaty > Bishkek > Tashkent when it comes to just cities. Almaty had the best infrastructure, public spaces, high-class amenities for the region and felt fresh. I liked Bishkek, but it doesn't have as much development flow. Tashkent disappointed me, for being one of the largest cities of the USSR.

They all have great Soviet remnants. Museums, architecture, metro systems. Very interesting to see the same components, construction styles, art in different climates with different ethnicities.

Samarkand is something special. I would spend more time in Almaty. Everything in the CIS countries has gotten more expensive since February.
